abstract.text: An operation for executing queries in a database.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A

object is a concrete operation that you can use to execute queries. A query operation applies query parameters to the specified database and record zone, delivering any matching records asynchronously to the handlers that you provide.
To perform a new search:
Initialize a
object with a
object that contains the search criteria and sorting information for the records you want.
Assign a handler to the
property so that you can process the results and execute the operation.

If the search yields many records, the operation object may deliver a portion of the total results to your blocks immediately, along with a cursor for obtaining the remaining records. Use the cursor to initialize and execute a separate
instance when you’re ready to process the next batch of results.
3. Optionally, configure the results by specifying values for the
and
properties.
4. Pass the query operation object to the
method of the target database to execute the operation.

CloudKit restricts queries to the records in a single record zone. For new queries, you specify the zone when you initialize the query operation object. For cursor-based queries, the cursor contains the zone information. To search for records in multiple zones, you must create a separate
object for each zone you want to search, although you can initialize each of them with the same
object.
If you assign a handler to the operation’s

property, the operation calls it after it executes and returns any results. Use a handler to perform housekeeping tasks for the operation, but don’t use it to process the results of the operation. The handler you provide should manage any failures, whether due to an error or an explicit cancellation.

abstract.text: Store structured app and user data in iCloud containers that all users of your app can share.
Executes the specified operation in the current database.
The abstract base class for operations that act upon databases in CloudKit.
An object for sorting records that contain location data.
A query that describes the criteria to apply when searching for records in a database.
An operation for executing queries in a database.
An object that marks the stopping point for a query and the starting point for retrieving the remaining results.
The  cursor for continuing the search.
The fields of the records to fetch.
The fields of the records to fetch.
Creates an empty query operation.
Creates an operation with additional results from a previous search.
Creates an operation that searches for records in the specified record zone.
A constant value that represents the maximum number of results CloudKit retrieves.
The query for the search.
The closure to execute after CloudKit retrieves all of the records.
The closure to execute when a record becomes available.
The maximum number of records to return at one time.
The ID of the record zone that contains the records to search.
The block to execute after the operation’s main task is completed.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
